column4: I just installed using Wubi a week or two ago...I'm getting to the point where I want to try installing windows programs (using Wine) to see if I want to replace Windows entirely...I need more space though
I followed the instructions here: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/WubiGuide#head-5aac3daad4eb9fcc3502ba1a4d6891b71b050b1d
how do I access the new one?

I installed using Wubi, and created a new virtual disk using these instructions: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/WubiGuide#head-5aac3daad4eb9fcc3502ba1a4d6891b71b050b1d - how do I access the new virtual disk?
so does anyone know how to access a newly created virtual disk made for a Wubi-installed Ubuntu?
ugh, okay
though, BTW...as a tool for introducing people to Linux who are hesitant to try it...Wubi is very nice
could use better support though :-p
from where you want to access the ubuntu drive?
from inside Ubuntu...I want to set up Wine to use the newly created virtual drive as it's C: drive
I am not sure what you want. But from ubuntu the whole root ( / ) is THIS drive
so / is a combination of what I had originally (root.disk, set up by Wubi) and the win.disk that I created?
you have created a win disk? how?
you probably mean the drive  ~/.wine/drive_c/ ... yes this is part of your ubuntu drive

It's just a virtual disk, apparently usable by Ubuntu...I created a file of the desired size and formatted it to ext3 using these instrunctions: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/WubiGuide#head-5aac3daad4eb9fcc3502ba1a4d6891b71b050b1d
I see now... yes this drive should also be mounted at /host/ubuntu/disks
so I need to mount it you're saying? How do I do that?
I hope it already is: try to go to /host/ubuntu/disks and look if there are subdirectories, these should be your virtual disks mounted
/host/ubuntu/disks just has the 3 .disk files in it :-(
I dont understand why its not mentioned where the additional space gets mounted... a gap in the manual. try: locate extra.disk
, isnt it somewhere on the desktop? normally ubuntu shows auto-mounted drives directly on the desktop
yes maybe... lets try mounting it then: sudo mount -a
